title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Observational Studies
Definition: Researchers observe choices or outcomes without assigning treatments.

Retrospective: Looking at past data (e.g., examining medical records of people who already have a disease).
Prospective: Following subjects into the future to observe outcomes (e.g., tracking a cohort of smokers vs. non-smokers).


Key Takeaway: Observational studies can show association, but they cannot prove causation.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Experiments: Basic Terminology
To prove causation, we need an Experiment, where we manipulate conditions.

Response Variable: What we measure at the end (e.g., Tomato weight).
Factors: The explanatory variables we manipulate (e.g., Fertilizer Type, Water Amount).
Levels: The specific values chosen for a factor.

Fertilizer Levels: None, Brand A, Brand B
Water Levels: 500ml, 1000ml

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Defining Treatments
A Treatment is a specific combination of the levels of each factor assigned to a subject.
Example: Growing Tomatoes
Combining the factors from the previous slide (3 Fertilizer levels \(\times\) 2 Water levels) creates 6 Distinct Treatments:



None + 500ml
None + 1000ml
Brand A + 500ml



Brand A + 1000ml
Brand B + 500ml
Brand B + 1000ml

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
The Four Principles of Design
To create a valid experiment, we follow four principles:

Control: Make conditions as similar as possible for all groups (e.g., same sunlight, same soil).
Randomize: Equalize the effects of unknown or uncontrollable sources of variation.
Replicate: Use enough subjects so that differences aren’t just chance anecdotes.
Block: Group similar subjects together before randomizing to reduce variability.

Diagrams
De Veaux emphasizes drawing diagrams to “Think” through the design.

Start with the Pool of subjects.
Block (if necessary) based on a variable you can’t control but think matters (e.g., tomato variety).
Branch out to Random Assignment (Crucial step!).
List the specific Treatments.
End with the Response comparison.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Blinding and Placebos
Humans are biased. We must manage that bias.

Placebo: A “fake” treatment that looks like the real thing used in the control group.
The Placebo Effect: Subjects often improve just because they believe they are being treated.
Blinding:

Single-blind: The subject doesn’t know which treatment they got.
Double-blind: Neither the subject nor the evaluator knows who got what (Gold Standard).

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Confounding
The Enemy of Inference.
When the levels of one factor are associated with the levels of another factor in such a way that their effects cannot be separated.

Example: If you test a new teaching method only in morning classes and the old method only in afternoon classes. If scores improve, was it the method or the time of day? Time of day is confounding the results.
Randomization is the cure for confounding.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Summary: Think, Show, Tell

Think: Is this an experiment or an observational study? Can I make a causal claim?
Show: Diagram your experiment. Ensure you have Controlled, Randomized, Replicated, and Blocked.
Tell: Interpret the results. “The difference in response is statistically significant…” (meaning unlikely to have occurred by chance).
